channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: New debris, apparently suitcase remnants, also found
MH370 maps
item.description: Malaysia Airlines flight 370 disappeared less than an hour after it took off from Kuala Lumpur. Here are maps showing what happened.

item.title: Experts answer your questions
item.description: Since Wednesday's discovery of what could very well be fragments of the long missing flight MH370, questions are once again being asked by the public on what this means, and whether the mystery of the missing plane might finally be solved.

item.title: Police: 6 stabbed at Jerusalem pride parade
Canadian pastor held in N. Korea speaks
Airline sued: Obese neighbor 'injured me'
item.description: Middle Eastern carrier faces Australian court battle after over alleged back injury sustained during Dubai-Sydney flight

item.title: Billionaire: I'll save FIFA from 'disgrace'
item.description: Could a billionaire automotive magnate be the man to drive reform at the top of world football?

item.title: 'Dark Knight' killer jury deliberates
item.description: Jurors began deliberating Thursday on whether to continue death penalty proceedings against convicted mass murderer James Holmes or to now sentence him to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

item.title: Recordings show Lafayette chaos
item.description: The tension and adrenaline are audible.

item.title: Officials: 'Jihadi John' alive
item.description: The U.S. government has "very recent indications" that "Jihadi John" -- the notorious, English-speaking, hooded ISIS executioner seen in violent hostage beheading videos -- is alive and most likely hiding in or near the self-declared ISIS capital of Raqqa, Syria, two U.S. officials told CNN on Thursday.

item.title: White House blasts reps' vacations
item.description: It's become a summer ritual in Washington: take a shot at the opposing party for taking a longer vacation than yours.

item.title: Russia vetoes U.N. MH17 tribunal
item.description: Russia has blocked a U.N. Security Council resolution that would have created an international tribunal to prosecute those responsible for bringing down Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 over Ukraine.

item.title: Ai Weiwei in UK visa dispute
item.description: Chinese artist Ai Weiwei has accused the UK government of denying him a full six-month business visa on the grounds he failed to declare a criminal conviction -- despite the fact he disputes ever being charged with or convicted of a crime.

item.title: 'Legal status' OK by Trump
item.description: Donald Trump, the Republican presidential hopeful who shot up to the head of the pack over his controversial comments about illegal immigrants, is finally starting to lay out an immigration policy.

item.title: Tough guy Perry challenges Trump
item.description: The war of words between businessman Donald Trump and former Texas Gov. Rick Perry reached the jungle gym on Wednesday, when Perry challenged Trump to a pull-up contest.

item.title: How man made $9M on Kickstarter
item.description: Exploding Kittens had more backers than any other campaign in Kickstarter history. Now, it's gone from a labor of love to a bona fide business.

item.title: Bolt: Time to ditch junk food
Sex scandal rocks kung fu monks
The young, raw Elvis Presley
item.description: Sixty-one years ago Thursday -- on July 30, 1954 -- 19-year-old Elvis Presley made his first live, professional appearance at a concert in Memphis, Tennessee. A new book from Taschen, "Elvis and the Birth of Rock and Roll," brings together photos from legendary photographer Alfred Wertheimer.

item.title: Mullah Omar dead? What next for Taliban
Is Trump turning U.S. into farce?
item.description: The American electoral circus has taken the stage and people around the world are watching in disbelief. To say they are not impressed would be an understatement. A Colombian columnist called Donald Trump a "lab rat," for testing the U.S. tolerance of toxic political debate. In India, a commentator writes dismissively that the "self-declared 'greatest' democracy is descending into a farce."

item.title: One mistake entrepreneurs should avoid
item.description: Getting it wrong is part of starting a business -- so what should entrepreneurs avoid?

item.title: How to Instragram like a pro
Does this man have U.S.' most dangerous job?
item.description: Until you get to know Sean D. Tucker, it's hard to understand why he chooses to make a living by risking his life.

item.title: Woman who defied dictator behind bars in U.S.
item.description: She personified courage as the woman who defied an iron-fisted dictator. Four years later, Eman al-Obeidi is just another inmate in a Colorado jail.

item.title: The spread of ancient religion through 11 sculptures
item.description: A new permanent gallery at Singapore's Asian Civilizations Museum traces 1,000 years of religious art and symbolism, looking at their spread out of India into China, Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia.

item.title: The children for sale on U.S. streets
item.description: The image sticks in my mind: A female defendant is escorted into the courtroom with shackles around her ankles, making it difficult to walk. Dressed in a jail-issued jumpsuit and flip-flops, she takes a seat at the appointed table up front, until the judge is gaveled in and we all rise.

item.title: Opinion: The myth of child prostitution
item.description: Last week saw the premiere of "Children for Sale: The Fight to End Human Trafficking," which exposes the hidden realities of child sex trafficking in the United States. It's a powerful documentary. But there's even more to the story.

item.title: Why Atlanta is hub of U.S. trafficking
item.description: The pathway leading to the dark corners of human trafficking began in the fluorescent-flooded hallways of a Florida middle school.

item.title: How do countries rank for trafficking?
item.description: Cuba, Kenya and Saudi Arabia are doing better at fighting human trafficking. Egypt, Ghana and Bulgaria are doing worse.

item.title: Mets' shortstop weeps on field amid trade rumors
Meet the soccer star with 'four birthdays'
This could be the heaviest wipe-out in history
Google Street View crashes Mongolian horse festival ...
Have you tried America's best pizza?
Are kids getting the best inflight food ?
Glorious silks add extra glamor to Goodwood Ladies Day
16 years of fire, art and nudity at Burning Man
Cecil the lion's killer thought hunt was legal
item.description: An American dentist is apologizing for killing a lion in Zimbabwe after its death sparked global outrage. CNN's David McKenzie reports.

item.title: 2001: Mullah Omar's extravagant compound
item.description: In 2001, CNN's Christiane Amanpour toured the former compound of Taliban leader Mullah Omar.

item.title: One tree grows 40 different types of fruit
item.description: Artist Sam Van Aken has created a series of trees that grow dozens of different types of stone fruits. He tells a TEDxManhattan conference that these trees are a research project, an art exhibit and a conservation mission.

item.title: The world shouldn't forget Ukraine's deadly war
item.description: CNN's Christiane Amanpour looks at the current situation in Ukraine and explains why it can't become a forgotten war.

item.title: Man going to jail for petting cougar at zoo
item.description: Josh Newell leaped over a Columbus Zoo barrier to pet a cougar, now he will find himself caged. CNN affiliate WBNS reports.

item.title: 15-foot python found hunting pets
item.description: A man discovered a nearly 15-foot Burmese python on his property after small animals began disappearing. CNN affiliate KTVI has the story.

item.title: Big beasts, big business: Cashing in on wildlife tours
From posers to exhibitionists: Yoga personality types revealed
item.description: Yoga's popularity, which has almost doubled in the past 10 years in the U.S., has ushered in a rash of newbies unaware of the teaching's finicky (and often justified) unwritten rules.

item.title: Have you tried America's best pizza?
The homeowners who refused to budge
Beirut's 1960s jet-set playgrounds
item.description: For several decades the name "Beirut" has conjured images of devastation and danger.

item.title: Buildings on verge of destruction
item.description: Go see them now, before it's too late: threatened by neglect, the elements, changing architectural trends or ruthless developers, these outstanding buildings are all fighting a hard battle for survival.

item.title: World's 10 most scenic airport approaches
item.description: For jaded air travelers, window seats are overrated.

item.title: Ruins of the Soviet space shuttle program
item.description: What was once the gleaming pride and joy of the Soviet space program now lies covered in dirt and bird droppings in a disused hangar in Kazakhstan.

item.title: NASA finds 'Earth's bigger, older cousin'
item.description: NASA said Thursday that its Kepler spacecraft has spotted "Earth's bigger, older cousin": the first nearly Earth-size planet to be found in the habitable zone of a star similar to our own.

item.title: The king with 100 wives
item.description: Abumbi II, the 11th fon, or king, of Bafut, Cameroon, has close to 100 wives. They weren't all his to start. According to local tradition, when a fon dies, his successor inherits all his wives and then marries his own queens.

item.title: 10 watches that changed history
item.description: Mechanical watchmaking is not a world of revolutions, it's a world of evolutions, where change comes only slowly and tradition is a sacred trust. In the five hundred or so years that watches have existed, however, there have been a few that have changed the watchmaking world. Some of these watches broke new ground in design, some in technology -- and some both. Here are ten that made history and became part of it at the same time.

item.title: Girl from Vietnam War photo: Where is she?
item.description: Even without the benefit of context, the image of a naked 9-year-old girl running for her life is as searing and indelible today as it was 43 years ago.

item.title: Capturing beauty around the world
item.description: To photographer Mihaela Noroc, beauty cannot be defined by one country, race or ethnicity.
